I don't like charter schools. I believe in public education. However, the problem with public education as presently constituted is doomed to failure. Here is my formula.
Starting teachers must pass an exam to become a teacher. They must serve a two-year apprenticeship under a mentor teacher. They start at a salary of 100,000 dollars which can rise to 150,000 in ten years. Curriculum, lesson plans and homework assignments are universalized and available on line. Communities can hire an administrative staff, but have no say on the hiring or firing of teachers. Disruptors, or students who misbehave within a pattern of misbehavior for whatever reason are shunned from the system. The school day is extended to 5 o'clock and students do their homework in school from the hours of 3 to 5. No summer vacations. Classes are tracked according to the performance of the students. Standardized tests are abolished as a standard for public universities which should be free. Admission is predicated on degree of performance with respect to the master curriculum, inclusive of extra-curricular activities. Standards for graduation of high schools include a certain reading level, math level, foreign language level, and social science level. There is a dress code for students and a standard of ethics. There is a cost to this model, but it is a fraction of what is returned.

First of all, Jon, the Second Amendment explicitly refers to the need for a "well-regulated militia" as the impetus for specifying a right to bear arms. The language does not imply that thermonuclear warheads must be permitted to private citizens, nor was anyone in the 18th century thinking about automatic weapons or, for that matter, anything other than a muzzle-loaded flintlock musket.

But times change, and we must find a way to apply the fundamental values embodied in the Constitution and the Bill of Rights to modern-day questions never dreamed of by the Framers. Modern personal weaponry that is standard issue to infantrymen in 2013 may be thought of as the functional equivalent of a musket in 1789, and consequently the right to bear that arm can be seen as Constitutionally protected.

Similarly, when modern contraception became commonplace the Supreme Court looked at all of the guaranties of personal liberty explicitly protected by the Constitution and found there was an underlying value of personal privacy that prohibited the government of Connecticut from forbidding condoms to married couples. That same principle was applied to abortions and to the rights of homosexuals.

Were it not for our ability to preserve the spirit while adapting the letter of the law we'd still be locking up people for coveting their neighbor's ox. We can certainly debate each case, but blindly adhering to a literal reading of rules written for a time long past is indefensible.
